text: that that part of the film on the train
is the one which was the where we really
drew the most from sort of old Hitchcock
films you know whether it was not like
North by Northwest or other things and
and we were trying to create some sort
of a classic feel it's a contemporary
thriller but there was something classic
about the story and and classic about
the idea of a relationship between two
strangers on a train so on an aesthetic
level that sort of we tried to borrow
from that and that came out in the in
the in the grade of the final film and
also in the in the wardrobe that Jake
was wearing you know he's got this sort
of schoolteachers uniform jacket and tie
a sort of an every man and every man
uniform there was an early choice as to
early on when we were in pre-production
as to whether we were going to try and
shoot it on a real train or shoot it in
a soundstage and what we ended up doing
was going with the soundstage and the
reason that was really important was
because we revisit an event multiple
times it was really really it was
absolutely integral to making at work
and for the audience not to get bored
that we were able to vary the visuals
and the way that I filmed the interior
of the Train and in order to do that we
had to be able to build platforms
outside of the train and be able to sort
of really vary the camera angles I'm and
use some some fairly large pieces of
equipment for some of our special
effects shots so we built something
called a gimbal which is basically a
device that allows us to sort of move
the set around we built the train set on
top of that and we were able to rock the
rock the train as we were shooting it
and actually repeat that action each
time
